metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Python Functions
A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called.
content.html: A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called.

content.text: You can pass data, known as parameters, into a function.
content.html: You can pass data, known as parameters, into a function.

content.text: A function can return data as a result.
content.html: A function can return data as a result.

content.text: Creating a Function
In Python a function is defined using the def keyword:
content.html: In Python a function is defined using the def keyword:

syntaxHighlighting.text: def my_function():  print("Hello from a function")

content.code: def my_function():  print("Hello from a function")

syntax_highlighting.text: def my_function():  print("Hello from a function")

content.code_html:
def my_function():
  print("Hello from a function")

syntax_highlighting_data.text: def my_function():  print("Hello from a function")

content.text: Calling a Function
To call a function, use the function name followed by parenthesis:
content.html: To call a function, use the function name followed by parenthesis:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def my_function():  print("Hello from a function")
  my_function()

content.code:
def my_function():  print("Hello from a function")
my_function()

syntax_highlighting.text:
def my_function():  print("Hello from a function")
 my_function()

content.code_html:
def my_function():
  print("Hello from a function")

my_function()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
def my_function():  print("Hello from a function")
  my_function()

content.text: Arguments
Information can be passed into functions as arguments.
content.html: Information can be passed into functions as arguments.

content.text: Arguments are specified after the function name, inside the parentheses. You can add as many arguments as you want, just separate them with a comma.
content.html: Arguments are specified after the function name, inside the parentheses. You can add as many arguments as you want, just separate them with a comma.

content.text: The following example has a function with one argument (fname). When the function is called, we pass along a first name, which is used inside the function to print the full name:
content.html: The following example has a function with one argument (fname). When the function is called, we pass along a first name, which is used inside the function to print the full name:

content.code:
def my_function(fname):  print(fname + " Refsnes")
my_function("Emil")my_function("Tobias")my_function("Linus")
content.code_html:
def my_function(fname):
  print(fname + " Refsnes")

my_function("Emil")
my_function("Tobias")
my_function("Linus")

content.text: Arguments are often shortened to args in Python documentations.
content.html: Arguments are often shortened to args in Python documentations.

content.text: Parameters or Arguments?
The terms parameter and argument can be used for the same thing: information that are passed into a function.
content.html: The terms parameter and argument can be used for the same thing: information that are passed into a function.

content.text: From a function's perspective:
content.html: From a function's perspective:

content.text: A parameter is the variable listed inside the parentheses in the function definition.
content.html: A parameter is the variable listed inside the parentheses in the function definition.

content.text: An argument is the value that is sent to the function when it is called.
content.html: An argument is the value that is sent to the function when it is called.

content.text: Number of Arguments
By default, a function must be called with the correct number of arguments. Meaning that if your function expects 2 arguments, you have to call the function with 2 arguments, not more, and not less.
content.html: By default, a function must be called with the correct number of arguments. Meaning that if your function expects 2 arguments, you have to call the function with 2 arguments, not more, and not less.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def my_function(fname, lname):  print(fname + " " + lname)
  my_function("Emil", "Refsnes")

content.code:
def my_function(fname, lname):  print(fname + " " + lname)
my_function("Emil", "Refsnes")

syntax_highlighting.text:
def my_function(fname, lname):  print(fname + " " + lname)
  my_function("Emil", "Refsnes")

content.code_html:
def my_function(fname, lname):
  print(fname + " " + lname)

my_function("Emil", "Refsnes")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
def my_function(fname, lname):  print(fname + " " + lname)
  my_function("Emil", "Refsnes")

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def my_function(fname, lname):  print(fname + " " + lname)
  my_function("Emil")

content.code:
def my_function(fname, lname):  print(fname + " " + lname)
my_function("Emil")

syntax_highlighting.text:
def my_function(fname, lname):  print(fname + " " + lname)
  my_function("Emil")

content.code_html:
def my_function(fname, lname):
  print(fname + " " + lname)

my_function("Emil")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
def my_function(fname, lname):  print(fname + " " + lname)
  my_function("Emil")

content.text: Arbitrary Arguments, *args
If you do not know how many arguments that will be passed into your function, add a * before the parameter name in the function definition.
content.html: If you do not know how many arguments that will be passed into your function, add a * before the parameter name in the function definition.

content.text: This way the function will receive a tuple of arguments, and can access the items accordingly:
content.html: This way the function will receive a tuple of arguments, and can access the items accordingly:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def my_function(*kids):  print("The youngest child 
  is " + kids[2])
  my_function("Emil", "Tobias", "Linus")

content.code:
def my_function(*kids):  print("The youngest child
is " + kids[2])
my_function("Emil", "Tobias", "Linus")

syntax_highlighting.text:
def my_function(*kids):  print("The youngest child 
  is " + kids[2])
  my_function("Emil", "Tobias", "Linus")

content.code_html:
def my_function(*kids):
  print("The youngest child is " + kids[2])

my_function("Emil", "Tobias", "Linus")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
def my_function(*kids):  print("The youngest child 
  is " + kids[2])
  my_function("Emil", "Tobias", "Linus")

content.text: Arbitrary Arguments are often shortened to *args in Python documentations.
content.html: Arbitrary Arguments are often shortened to *args in Python documentations.

content.text: Keyword Arguments
You can also send arguments with the key = value syntax.
content.html: You can also send arguments with the key = value syntax.

content.text: This way the order of the arguments does not matter.
content.html: This way the order of the arguments does not matter.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def my_function(child3, child2, child1):  print("The youngest child 
  is " + child3)
  my_function(child1 = "Emil", child2 = "Tobias", child3 = "Linus")

content.code:
def my_function(child3, child2, child1):  print("The youngest child
is " + child3)
my_function(child1 = "Emil", child2 = "Tobias", child3 = "Linus")

syntax_highlighting.text:
def my_function(child3, child2, child1):  print("The youngest child 
  is " + child3)
  my_function(child1 = "Emil", child2 = "Tobias", child3 = "Linus")

content.code_html:
def my_function(child3, child2, child1):
  print("The youngest child is " + child3)

my_function(child1 = "Emil", child2 = "Tobias", child3 = "Linus")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
def my_function(child3, child2, child1):  print("The youngest child 
  is " + child3)
  my_function(child1 = "Emil", child2 = "Tobias", child3 = "Linus")

content.text: The phrase Keyword Arguments are often shortened to kwargs in Python documentations.
content.html: The phrase Keyword Arguments are often shortened to kwargs in Python documentations.

content.text: Arbitrary Keyword Arguments, **kwargs
If you do not know how many keyword arguments that will be passed into your function, add two asterisk: ** before the parameter name in the function definition.
content.html: If you do not know how many keyword arguments that will be passed into your function, add two asterisk: ** before the parameter name in the function definition.

content.text: This way the function will receive a dictionary of arguments, and can access the items accordingly:
content.html: This way the function will receive a dictionary of arguments, and can access the items accordingly:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def my_function(**kid):  print("His last name is " + kid["lname"])
  my_function(fname = "Tobias", lname = "Refsnes")

content.code:
def my_function(**kid):  print("His last name is " + kid["lname"])
my_function(fname = "Tobias", lname = "Refsnes")

syntax_highlighting.text:
def my_function(**kid):  print("His last name is " + kid["lname"])
 my_function(fname = "Tobias", lname = "Refsnes")

content.code_html:
def my_function(**kid):
  print("His last name is " + kid["lname"])

my_function(fname = "Tobias", lname = "Refsnes")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
def my_function(**kid):  print("His last name is " + kid["lname"])
  my_function(fname = "Tobias", lname = "Refsnes")

content.text: Arbitrary Kword Arguments are often shortened to **kwargs in Python documentations.
content.html: Arbitrary Kword Arguments are often shortened to **kwargs in Python documentations.

content.text: Default Parameter Value
The following example shows how to use a default parameter value.
content.html: The following example shows how to use a default parameter value.

content.text: If we call the function without argument, it uses the default value:
content.html: If we call the function without argument, it uses the default value:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def my_function(country = "Norway"):  print("I am from " + 
  country)
  my_function("Sweden")my_function("India")my_function()my_function("Brazil")

content.code:
def my_function(country = "Norway"):  print("I am from " +
country)
my_function("Sweden")my_function("India")my_function()my_function("Brazil")

syntax_highlighting.text:
def my_function(country = "Norway"):  print("I am from " + 
  country)
  my_function("Sweden")my_function("India")my_function()my_function("Brazil")

content.code_html:
def my_function(country = "Norway"):
  print("I am from " + country)

my_function("Sweden")
my_function("India")
my_function()
my_function("Brazil")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
def my_function(country = "Norway"):  print("I am from " + 
  country)
  my_function("Sweden")my_function("India")my_function()my_function("Brazil")

content.text: Passing a List as an Argument
You can send any data types of argument to a function (string, number, list, dictionary etc.), and it will be treated as the same data type inside the function.
content.html: You can send any data types of argument to a function (string, number, list, dictionary etc.), and it will be treated as the same data type inside the function.

content.text: E.g. if you send a List as an argument, it will still be a List when it reaches the function:
content.html: E.g. if you send a List as an argument, it will still be a List when it reaches the function:

content.code_html:
def my_function(food):
  for x in food:
    print(x)

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

my_function(fruits)

content.text: Return Values
To let a function return a value, use the return statement:
content.html: To let a function return a value, use the return statement:

content.code:
def my_function(x):  return 5 * xprint(my_function(3))print(my_function(5))
print(my_function(9))
content.code_html:
def my_function(x):
  return 5 * x

print(my_function(3))
print(my_function(5))
print(my_function(9))

content.text: The pass Statement
function definitions cannot be empty, but if you for some reason have a function definition with no content, put in the pass statement to avoid getting an error.
content.html: function definitions cannot be empty, but if you for some reason have a function definition with no content, put in the pass statement to avoid getting an error.

content.code: def myfunction():  pass
content.code_html:
def myfunction():
  pass

content.text: Positional-Only Arguments
You can specify that a function can have ONLY positional arguments, or ONLY keyword arguments.
content.html: You can specify that a function can have ONLY positional arguments, or ONLY keyword arguments.

content.text: To specify that a function can have only positional arguments, add , / after the arguments:
content.html: To specify that a function can have only positional arguments, add , / after the arguments:

content.code: def my_function(x, /):  print(x)my_function(3)
content.code_html:
def my_function(x, /):
  print(x)

my_function(3)

content.text: Without the , / you are actually allowed to use keyword arguments even if the function expects positional arguments:
content.html: Without the , / you are actually allowed to use keyword arguments even if the function expects positional arguments:

content.code: def my_function(x):  print(x)my_function(x = 3)
content.code_html:
def my_function(x):
  print(x)

my_function(x = 3)

content.text: But when adding the , / you will get an error if you try to send a keyword argument:
content.html: But when adding the , / you will get an error if you try to send a keyword argument:

content.code: def my_function(x, /):  print(x)my_function(x = 3)
content.code_html:
def my_function(x, /):
  print(x)

my_function(x = 3)

content.text: Keyword-Only Arguments
To specify that a function can have only keyword arguments, add *, before the arguments:
content.html: To specify that a function can have only keyword arguments, add *, before the arguments:

content.code: def my_function(*, x):  print(x)my_function(x = 3)
content.code_html:
def my_function(*, x):
  print(x)

my_function(x = 3)

content.text: Without the *, you are allowed to use positional arguments even if the function expects keyword arguments:
content.html: Without the *, you are allowed to use positional arguments even if the function expects keyword arguments:

content.code: def my_function(x):  print(x)my_function(3)
content.code_html:
def my_function(x):
  print(x)

my_function(3)

content.text: But with the *, you will get an error if you try to send a positional argument:
content.html: But with the *, you will get an error if you try to send a positional argument:

content.code: def my_function(*, x):  print(x)my_function(3)
content.code_html:
def my_function(*, x):
  print(x)

my_function(3)

content.text: Combine Positional-Only and Keyword-Only
You can combine the two argument types in the same function.
content.html: You can combine the two argument types in the same function.

content.text: Any argument before the / , are positional-only, and any argument after the *, are keyword-only.
content.html: Any argument before the / , are positional-only, and any argument after the *, are keyword-only.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def my_function(a, b, /, *, c, d):  print(a + b + c + d)
  my_function(5, 6, c = 7, d = 8)

content.code:
def my_function(a, b, /, *, c, d):  print(a + b + c + d)
my_function(5, 6, c = 7, d = 8)

syntax_highlighting.text:
def my_function(a, b, /, *, c, d):  print(a + b + c + d)
  my_function(5, 6, c = 7, d = 8)

content.code_html:
def my_function(a, b, /, *, c, d):
  print(a + b + c + d)

my_function(5, 6, c = 7, d = 8)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
def my_function(a, b, /, *, c, d):  print(a + b + c + d)
  my_function(5, 6, c = 7, d = 8)

content.text: Recursion
Python also accepts function recursion, which means a defined function can call itself.
content.html: Python also accepts function recursion, which means a defined function can call itself.

content.text: Recursion is a common mathematical and programming concept. It means that a function calls itself. This has the benefit of meaning that you can loop through data to reach a result.
content.html: Recursion is a common mathematical and programming concept. It means that a function calls itself. This has the benefit of meaning that you can loop through data to reach a result.

content.text: The developer should be very careful with recursion as it can be quite easy to slip into writing a function which never terminates, or one that uses excess amounts of memory or processor power. However, when written correctly recursion can be a very efficient and mathematically-elegant approach to programming.
content.html: The developer should be very careful with recursion as it can be quite easy to slip into writing a function which never terminates, or one that uses excess amounts of memory or processor power. However, when written correctly recursion can be a very efficient and mathematically-elegant approach to programming.

content.text: In this example, tri_recursion() is a function that we have defined to call itself ("recurse"). We use the k variable as the data, which decrements ( -1 ) every time we recurse. The recursion ends when the condition is not greater than 0 (i.e. when it is 0).
content.html: In this example, tri_recursion() is a function that we have defined to call itself ("recurse"). We use the k variable as the data, which decrements (-1) every time we recurse. The recursion ends when the condition is not greater than 0 (i.e. when it is 0).

content.text: To a new developer it can take some time to work out how exactly this works, best way to find out is by testing and modifying it.
content.html: To a new developer it can take some time to work out how exactly this works, best way to find out is by testing and modifying it.

content.code_html:
def tri_recursion(k):
  if(k > 0):
    result = k + tri_recursion(k - 1)
    print(result)
  else:
    result = 0
  return result

print("Recursion Example Results:")
tri_recursion(6)
